div.p: S. D. I hope, my brother, that you have already received our letters along with the token of love enclosed; then you will understand that your letters, which you had entrusted to the coachman, have been delivered to us.
Take care diligently that the Duke of Württemberg does not spread pamphlets throughout France and incite disturbances and contentions.
That prince is diligent and in every way strives to impose Luther's doctrine of the Lord's Supper, that is, the Augsburg Confession with the Apology, on everyone.
Otherwise, he is a good prince, but in this matter, he is astonishingly hasty.
Now disturbances have arisen in Saxony because of the Palatinate Catechism, with some approving it, others abhorring it.
They say that the prince has become Zwinglian and Calvinist.
You know that Sulcer subscribed in Strasbourg to the cause of Zanchi, to the Augsburg Confession and the Apology.
You know that Eber wrote a book against our doctrine on the supper, in which there are many absurdities.
In the German example, he has Calvin's name, which he openly connects with Zwingli's, but he did not include it in the Latin version.
The envoy of the King of France argued with me a lot about forming a treaty with the king, and that at your command, who had discussed this matter with him in Basel.
I think he made it all up.
For I hear that he is not to be trusted.
I have not read Ochino's book, nor would I have time to read it. However, I do not think he aligns with the Servetians, Grybaldists, and Blandratists, whom he openly curses.
And to Thretio, who was about to depart for Poland, he solemnly affirmed that he abhors the Italians in Poland who dispute against the worship of the Trinity.
He also promised to give him letters against those scoundrels.
And he did, if I am not mistaken.
Therefore, if he refutes strong arguments with weaker ones, I attribute it more to ignorance and senile delirium than to malice.
In recent days, his wife died from a serious accident, leaving him with children, etc.
He is very miserable.
I think he, being very afflicted, will not survive others for long.
Regarding other matters, I have written to Mr. Calvin and Ionville.
I beg you to continue diligently writing to us about the affairs of France.
Farewell and love us. June 12, 1563.
Your Bullinger. Not reread.
